image.altText: A collage of two silhouettes, the KPMG logo, and cutouts of $100 notes.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant KPMG has been accused by whistleblowers of wasting public money, submitting inflated invoices and billing the Department of Defence for hours never worked.

title.children: It's raking in billions of dollars in public money. Now whistleblowers are accusing this consulting firm of ripping off the government

image.altText: Two sets of gloved hands hold the head of a baby, its face scrunched up, while it is being born.

items.synopsis: Midwives across the country say workforce shortages are taking a heavy toll on maternity staff and the families they care for.

title.children: The hands delivering this baby belong to two young midwives, stepping into a profession under immense stress

image.altText: A police exclusion zone following a fatal house fire on Russell Island

items.synopsis: Investigators are still sifting through the burnt-out house on Russell Island after the fire that killed a father and his five sons yesterday.

title.children: Police say cause of house fire requires 'closer scrutiny' after father and five sons killed

image.altText: Mushrooms stand on a patch of grass.

items.synopsis: A community in Victoria's east mourns the loss of three people as police and the health department continue to investigate suspected fatal mushroom poisonings.

title.children: Police investigate Victorian mushroom deaths as 'pillars' of community mourned

image.altText: A woman in a purple t-shirt reading vote yes weaving a basket while surrounded by others

items.synopsis: Supporters of the Yes campaign are still hopeful the referendum will pass but a growing number of No voters is putting it at risk, writes Dana Morse.

title.children: The Voice referendum campaign is becoming a tale of two polls and a political battle

image.altText: A composite image of Australia's Sam Kerr and Denmark's Sanne Troelsgaarda.

items.synopsis: Australia is set to play for a spot in the quarterfinals of the FIFA Women's World Cup tonight. Here's what you need to know before the Matildas run onto the pitch.

title.children: What time do the Matildas play tonight? Get up to speed

image.altText: Six feamle soccer players, wearing white, look upset after losing, with one on her knees, crying

items.synopsis: Two-time defending Women's World Cup champions USA are knocked out in the round of 16 by Sweden, 5-4 on penalties in Melbourne/Naarm.

title.children: USA suffer historic World Cup knock-out after dramatic penalty shoot-out

image.altText: A Matildas striker crouches low to the ground as she runs away from goal with arms spread, as teammates celebrate a goal.

items.synopsis: Australia are favourites to defeat Denmark in the round of 16. But does the team see itself in the same way?

title.children: Can the Matildas unshackle themselves from their underdog story to dominate Denmark?

image.altText: A woman smiling holding a baseball bat.

items.synopsis: When Carly Moore walks out onto the diamond in Canada this week, she will become the first South Australian to represent Australia at a Women's Baseball World Cup. She's hoping to inspire more local females to step up to the plate.

title.children: Carly is the first South Australian to play in the Women's Baseball World Cup, but she vows not to be the last

image.altText: A netball team gathers on court for a group shot holding an Australian flag as a sign says 'Champions' behind them.

items.synopsis: The Diamonds have "finished business" at the Netball World Cup, reclaiming the last piece of silverware missing from their trophy cabinet to clinch their 12th title.

title.children: Australia wins back Netball World Cup to send Ash Brazill out on a high

image.altText: Hundreds of Banksia Securities creditors met in Kyabram, Shepparton and Ballarat.

items.synopsis: After a decade, retirees who lost money in the collapse of Banksia Securities Limited are a step closer to getting their money. But the story remains an epic tale of the rich and powerful exploiting their standing to rip off the vulnerable, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Class actions are meant to help level the playing field. So how did this one go so wrong?

image.altText: A UH-60M Black Hawk in flight.

items.synopsis: Two new Black Hawks arrive in Australia, which will eventually form part of a 40-strong helicopter fleet to replace the army's troubled Taipans that remain grounded following last month's crash in Queensland.

title.children: Army's first new Black Hawks arrive as 'secretive' Taipan crash investigation continues

image.altText: Donald Trump, wearing a navy suit, holds his red tie down to stop it flapping as he descends airplane stairs

items.synopsis: The former US president says "there is no way I can get a fair trial" and he will seek Judge Tanya Chutkan's recusal as well as a change of venue.

title.children: Donald Trump seeks new judge in election fraud case

image.altText: A blonde white woman wearing a blue and white striped halter-neck and matching headband drives a bright pink car.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Barbie hits $US1 billion, and Zuckerberg and Musk bicker over teased 'cage fight': The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The man found guilty of murdering Michelle Bright in 1999 will spend at least 24 years behind bars. Family and friends of the 17-year-old clapped and sighed with relief when Justice Robert Allan Hulme sentenced Craig Rumsby to 32 years ' jail, with a non-parole period of 24 years. The 56-year-old was found guilty by a jury in June of murdering the high school student at Gulgong in the state's central west. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Craig Rumsby sentenced to 32 years' jail for 1999 murder of NSW teen

featuredLink.title: Man sentenced to 32 years' jail for 1999 murder of teenager Michelle Bright

props.alt: a woman in nineties style hair and clothes smiles at the camera

children.content: Michelle Bright was murdered in 1999
(NSW Police)
The man found guilty of murdering Michelle Bright in 1999 will spend at least
24 years
behind bars.
Family and friends of the 17-year-old
clapped and sighed with relief when Justice Robert Allan Hulme sentenced Craig Rumsby to
32 years
' jail, with a non-parole period of
24 years
The 56-year-old was
found guilty by a jury in June
of murdering the high school student at Gulgong in the state's central west.
You can keep reading this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former US president Donald Trump says he will seek a new judge in his election fraud case. Posting on his Truth Social social media platform he wrote, "There is no way I can get a fair trial with the judge assigned." He says he will seek US District Judge Tanya Chutkan's recusal as well as a change of venue outside of Washington. Trump last week pleaded not guilty to charges he conspired to defraud the US by preventing Congress from certifying Democratic rival Joe Biden's victory, depriving voters of their right to a fair election. You can continue reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Donald Trump wants a new judge for his election fraud case

featuredLink.title: Donald Trump seeks new judge in election fraud case

children.content: Former US president Donald Trump says he will seek a new judge in his election fraud case.
Posting on his Truth Social social media platform he wrote, "There is no way I can get a fair trial with the judge assigned."
He says he will seek US District Judge Tanya Chutkan's recusal as well as a change of venue outside of Washington.
Trump
last week pleaded not guilty to
charges
he conspired to defraud the US
by preventing Congress from certifying Democratic rival Joe Biden's victory, depriving voters of their right to a fair election.
You can continue reading this story here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The shadow minister for Indigenous Australians tells ABC News Breakfast that the annual Garma Festival — Australia's largest Indigenous gathering — is "a love-in for Labor". Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price also says Opposition Leader Peter Dutton didn't need to attend this year's event, which ends today, as he has already listened to Indigenous voices. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese attended this year's Garma. "Mr Dutton has been to Garma several times already, recently," the senator says. "It might be important for some but, for those who can afford to pay almost $3,000 to attend for four days, I mean, it's a love-in for Labor, for Mr Albanese. "I'd ask Mr Albanese to attend Alice Springs again and spend more time and listen to the vulnerable children in those communities, in the communities in Alice Springs, who would love to have $6 million poured into building accommodation to create a safe haven for them in a learning environment so that they're not at risk of being abused at night and can get an education. "But, instead, he attends where it's safe ground for him, where he knows that those around him support him. But he won't do the hard yards, and won't listen to Indigenous voices unless they're enshrined within a constitution, apparently."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shadow minister for Indigenous Australians calls Garma Festival 'a love-in for Labor'

props.alt: A woman in a suit gives a TV interview in front of a backdrop of Canberra Parliament House

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
The shadow minister for Indigenous Australians tells ABC News Breakfast that the annual Garma Festival — Australia's largest Indigenous gathering — is "a love-in for Labor".
Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price also says Opposition Leader Peter Dutton didn't need to attend this year's event
, which ends today, as he has already listened to Indigenous voices.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese attended this year's Garma.
"Mr Dutton has been to Garma several times already, recently," the senator says.
"It might be important for some but, for those who can afford to pay almost $3,000 to attend for four days, I mean, it's a love-in for Labor, for Mr Albanese.

"I'd ask Mr Albanese to attend Alice Springs again and spend more time and listen to the vulnerable children in those communities, in the communities in Alice Springs, who would love to have $6 million poured into building accommodation to create a safe haven for them in a learning environment so that they're not at risk of being abused at night and can get an education.

"But, instead, he attends where it's safe ground for him, where he knows that those around him support him. But he won't do the hard yards, and won't listen to Indigenous voices unless they're enshrined within a constitution, apparently."

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The ASX looks set for a subdued start to the week, following modest falls on Wall Street on Friday and with no major corporate profit results due out today. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX set for quiet start after Wall Street eases on disappointing jobs numbers

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US non-farm payrolls numbers were the major economic news on Friday, and moved both share and bond markets. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that 187,000 jobs were added to the US economy in July. That might sound like a lot, but it's pretty small in a country with around 335 million people. Combined with a downwardly revised jobs gain in June, which was even smaller, it is the weakest jobs growth in two and a half years. Economists were generally expecting around 200,000 jobs to be created. Despite the fall in jobs, unemployment fell from 3.6 to 3.5% and wages growth continued at an annual pace of 4.4% — down from recent peaks around 5%, but above expectations. "US Treasuries [bond prices] rallied immediately following the non-farm payroll headlines, from 4.20% to 4.10% in the first 90 minutes, and to below 4.05% during the afternoon to end the week at 4.034%, a fall of just 8bps on the week," wrote NAB's Ray Attrill. "The 2yr [yield] slumped from 4.945% quickly down to 4.80% with falls extended to 4.764% by the close to be 12bps down on the week. Pricing for a further 25bps Fed rate hike in September reduced from 17% to 13% ." However, Westpac's Imre Speizer said the data was not a major shock to the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee (which sets US central bank interest rates). "FOMC member Goolsbee said the jobs report was 'pretty much what we expected', the labour market cooling a little but still 'extremely strong'. He was not concerned about the sticky wage data, stressing wages are a backward looking indicator," Speizer observed.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US employment growth slows, but wages growth remains strong

children.content: The US non-farm payrolls numbers were the major economic news on Friday, and moved both share and bond markets.
The
Bureau of Labor Statistics
reported that
187,000 jobs were added to the US economy in July
That might sound like a lot, but it's pretty small in a country with around 335 million people.
Combined with a downwardly revised jobs gain in June, which was even smaller, it is the
weakest jobs growth in two and a half years
Economists were generally expecting around 200,000 jobs to be created.
Despite the fall in jobs,
unemployment fell from 3.6 to 3.5%
and
wages growth continued at an annual pace of 4.4%
— down from recent peaks around 5%, but above expectations.

"US Treasuries [bond prices] rallied immediately following the non-farm payroll headlines, from 4.20% to 4.10% in the first 90 minutes, and to below 4.05% during the afternoon to end the week at 4.034%, a fall of just 8bps on the week," wrote NAB's Ray Attrill.
"The 2yr [yield] slumped from 4.945% quickly down to 4.80% with falls extended to 4.764% by the close to be 12bps down on the week.
Pricing for a further 25bps Fed rate hike in September reduced from 17% to 13%
However,
Westpac's Imre Speizer
said the data was not a major shock to the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee (which sets US central bank interest rates).

"FOMC member Goolsbee said the jobs report was 'pretty much what we expected', the labour market cooling a little but still 'extremely strong'. He was not concerned about the sticky wage data, stressing wages are a backward looking indicator," Speizer observed.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, I'll be taking you through all of today's market action, hopefully with a couple of guest posts from Rachel Pupazzoni who's on the ground in Kalgoorlie for the annual Diggers and Dealers mining conference. There's likely to be more action there than on the ASX, where the futures are pointing to just a 0.2% decline at the open after Wall Street eased on Friday. Jobs data were the major driver for US stocks at the end of last week, coming in a bit weaker than expected although wages growth remained slightly higher (more on that in a few minutes). Locally, while reporting season ramps up this week, that is not today, with no major firms releasing profit results. In a post soon, I'll flag the main ones to look out for later this week. While there's not a lot of big news about, there's still plenty to talk about, so let's dive in.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to edge lower on signs of emerging US jobs weakness

While there's not a lot of big news about, there's still plenty to talk about, so let's dive in.

image.altText: A young girl with dark hair wearing a gold necklace and a dark coloured jacket stands in front of a white car, smiling

items.synopsis: The South Australian government says it will evaluate an opposition policy to incentivise P-platers to be more careful on the road, as the road toll climbs more rapidly than in a decade.

title.children: SA opposition announces young driver incentive plan

image.altText: VAR showing a ball just over the line from Sweden's match-winning penalty against USA at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The reigning champions are knocked out by VAR and a phenomenal goalkeeper, as Sam Kerr is set to finally take the field. Here are five talking points from the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Five quick hits — Sweden sinks USA by this much and Sam Kerr set for first World Cup minutes

image.altText: An elderly lady sits in front of a bookcase

items.synopsis: Renters searching for affordable housing have been at the forefront of Australia's housing crisis. But landlords say bad tenants and state-based reforms are making it tough for them too.

title.children: Been turned away from a rental? Here is why real estate agents, landlords say they are knocking people back

image.altText: An Aboriginal flag in the foreground, Parliament House in the background

items.synopsis: Millennials and members of Generation Z have never voted in a national referendum before, but they may decide whether the constitution changes this year.

title.children: Could young people lead Australia to vote Yes in the Voice to Parliament referendum?

image.altText: Stingrays with Foord

items.synopsis: These players have a training story to cherish for a lifetime after Caitlin Foord dropped in on her old club to dazzle them and the TV cameras with her skills.

title.children: How a groundskeeper with a nifty kick turned out to be a Matildas star

image.altText: Composite image of Andrew Forrest and Michael Woodley.

items.synopsis: With Fortescue and Pilbara native title holders unable to agree on compensation for "economic and cultural loss" caused by mining, the Federal Court will begin hearing evidence in Roebourne today.

title.children: Andrew Forrest's FMG, Pilbara traditional owners return to court over $500 million compensation battle

image.altText: A woman stands by a car with her arms crossed

items.synopsis: A mining boom and a government scheme to house its workers has made renting a home in this Northern Territory town almost impossible.

title.children: Vanessa lives in a shack outside Tennant Creek with no power or water. It was her only option

image.altText: A woman wearing a bright yellow jacket sits on an oversized soccer ball, a child sits on her lap. They're on a football field.

items.synopsis: FIFA is providing assistance to fans with autism, ADHD and PTSD, in the form of sensory rooms, visual cue cards and more. But does more need to be done?

title.children: Live sport can be challenging for neurodivergent fans. Here's what support is available at the Women's World Cup

image.altText: A generic photo of a woman by a lake looking at her phone at dusk, date unknown.

items.synopsis: One in six Australians feels severely lonely, and the people we are least socially connected to are our neighbours, according to a landmark study on social connections.

title.children: Feeling socially disconnected? Almost one-third of Australians feel the same way

image.altText: People stand around in red boat while another boat come towards them

items.synopsis: At least six people are dead and dozens are missing as several ships across the Mediterranean sink amid record migration.

title.children: Several migrant ships sink off Italy and Tunisia

image.altText: A building on fire with bright flames on the inside and smoke above

items.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy denounces the attack as a war crime as Ukraine also claims to have downed several Russian missiles.

title.children: Russia targets blood bank and airbase in latest strikes on Ukraine

image.altText: A woman with camera gear

items.synopsis: The program is teaching 20 First Nations and Indo-Pacific women sports commentary and mobile journalism at Brisbane Stadium during the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Next generation of sports journalists hone skills at World Cup

image.altText: Megan Rapinoe of USA kicks a penalty shot.

items.synopsis: Penalty shootouts are cruel at best, but this one sealed the most heartbreaking of exits for a hero of women's football; an exit all the more unfathomable because fate had been at her own feet, writes Kate O'Halloran.

title.children: A fairytale ending presented, but for once, Rapinoe and the USA couldn't take it

image.altText: Fire ant in extreme close up on a stick

items.synopsis: The Invasive Species Council says delays to the rollout of funding may be "catastrophic" for fire ant eradication efforts, based on its analysis of leaked government documents.

title.children: Fire ants winning battle against eradication due to 'bureaucratic delays', environment group says

image.altText: Cheyenne Paynter with french horn

items.synopsis: With most urban and suburban year 11 and 12 students in Tasmania still going to a dedicated seniors college, questions are being raised about the big teacher resources going to a handful of students in public high schools.

title.children: Tasmania's year 11 and 12 school system underwent a dramatic shake-up. Is it working?

image.altText: Shane Drumgold holding a folder walking into ACAT.

items.synopsis: The ACT's attorney-general says Shane Drumgold's role as director of public prosecutions is "no longer tenable" and he has accepted his resignation after his handling last year of the investigation into Bruce Lehrmann.

title.children: ACT's top prosecutor resigns after Lehrmann inquiry accuses him of 'serious misconduct'

image.altText: An old coloured photo of moustached man with tattoos on arm, a white vest, painting a window bar white, looks up at camera.

items.synopsis: This man was officially last seen at an Adelaide train station in 1994. But his brother-in-law insists that's not the last he saw of him.

title.children: Steve Lockey had been missing for two years. Then his brother-in-law walked into an outback pub

image.altText: Police officers gather at the site where a train derailed

items.synopsis: Ten cars on The Hazara Express derail near a town in the southern province of Sindh, around 275 kilometres from Pakistan's largest city Karachi, killing 30 and injuring many more.

title.children: At least 30 killed and more than 90 injured in Pakistan train derailment

image.altText: A man stares out at raging floodwaters in a village.

items.synopsis: A magnitude-5.5 earthquake strikes eastern China as rain continued to pelt the north-eastern regions in the wake of Typhoon Doksuri, adding more pressure to the country's struggle to recover its economy from the COVID pandemic.

title.children: China's economic losses from natural disasters surge to billions, adding more pressure to struggling economy
